case_name: Municipal Council of Bhopal v. Respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1547 of 1967 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1547 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated October 18, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Misc. Petition No. 557 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated October 18, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Jabalpur in Misc. Petition No. 557 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.-

facts.text: On 6-11-1964 the Municipal Council of Bhopal made bye-laws under the provisions of s. 356 7 f read with s. 349 ii of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961 after previous publication in the P. Rapatra as required under s. 357 4 and confirmation by the State Government under s. 357 3 in respect of a Municipal bus stand.

anchor.surface_text: On 6-11-1964 the Municipal Council of Bho- pal made bye-laws under the provisions of s. 356.  7   f  read with s. 349 ii  of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961 after previous publication in the P. Rapatra as required under s. 357  4  and companyfirmation by the State Government under s. 357  3  in respect of a Municipal bus stand.

facts.text: Bye-law 2 provided that person in charge of a motor-bus plying for hire shall for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers, park or stop his bus anywhere within the limits of the Bhopal Municipality except at the Municipal Bus Stand.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 2 of the bye-laws provided that numberperson in charge of a motor-bus plying for hire shall for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers, park or stop his bus anywhere within the limits of the Bhopal Municipality except at the Municipal Bus Stand.

facts.text: Other bye-laws provided for a levy of a fee of Re. 1/- for every eight hours or part thereof in respect of the use of the bus stand by such buses and for the issue of a permit on such payment.

anchor.surface_text: The other bye-laws provided for a levy of a fee of Re. 1/for every eight hours or part thereof in respect of the, use of the bus stand by such buses and for the issue of a permit on such payment.

facts.text: On 13-11-1964 the respondents filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh challenging the said bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: On 13-11-1964 the respondents filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh challenging the said bye-laws.

facts.text: High Court held that bye-law 1 c, which defined the expression Municipal Bus Stand and bye-law 2 were valid, but bye-laws 3 to 7 invalid, and restrained the Municipal Council from giving effect to those bye-laws and directed refund of fees collected from the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that bye-law 1  c , which defined the expression Municipal Bus Stand and bye-law 2, which has been set out earlier, were valid, but held by laws 3 to 7, which provided for the payment of fee and the giving of a permit etc., as invalid, and restrained the Municipal Council from giving effect to those bye-laws in any manner. The Municipal Council was also directed to refund the fee companylected from the respondents.

facts.text: This appeal has been filed by the Municipal Council by certificate granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed by the Municipal Council by certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: The respondents as well as the Municipal Council had stated that the District Magistrate had declared the Bhopal Municipal Bus Stand as a bus stand.

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to numbere that in this case the respondents as well as the Municipal Council had stated that the District Magistrate had declared the Bhopal Municipal Bus Stand as a bus stand.

facts.text: C. Chagla, Rameshwar Nath and Seeta Vaidialingam appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chagla, Rameshwar Nath and Seeta Vaidialingam, for the appellant.

facts.text: N. Phadke and A. G. Ratnaparkhi appeared for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: N. Phadke and A,. G. Ratnaparkhi, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: N. Shroff and R. P. Kapur appeared for respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: N. Shroff and R. P. Kapur, for respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Mr. M. C. Chagla made four points on behalf of the Municipal Council.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. M. C. Chagla, appearing for the Municipal Council, made those four points

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: by certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Municipal Council collected fees from the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Council was also directed to refund the fee companylected from the respondents.

facts.text: Bye-law 1(c) defined the expression Municipal Bus Stand.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that bye-law 1  c , which defined the expression Municipal Bus Stand

facts.text: District Magistrate declared Bhopal Municipal Bus Stand as a bus stand.

anchor.surface_text: the District Magistrate had declared the Bhopal Municipal Bus Stand as a bus stand.

issues.text: Whether Section 349(ii) of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961 enables the Municipal Council to charge fees for the use of the municipal bus stand by compelling buses to use it

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that S. 349 ii does number apply to this case. The relevant portion of that section reads The Council may charge such fee as may be prescribed.for any permission granted under this Act for the temporary occupation of any land belonging to the Council. The section itself does number enable the Municipal Council to require that permission should be obtained for any purpose. It deals with levy of fees for permissions which are required to be taken for various purposes under other sections of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Municipal Council can validly make the present bye-laws under the provisions of section 358(7)(f) and (n) of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961

anchor.surface_text: Let us number companysider if under the provisions of section 358, already extracted, the Municipal Council can validly make the present bylaws. It is number possible to relate the provision of clause f of subsection 7 as having anything to do with the provision of a bus stand. As regards clause n of sub-section 7 the regulating and prohibiting the stationing of carts on any ground under the companytrol of the Council or the using of such ground as halting place of vehicles cannot be said to relate to the provision of a Municipal bus stand.

issues.text: Whether the Municipal Council has the power under the Motor Vehicles Act to prohibit buses from picking up or setting down passengers except at the municipal bus stand

anchor.surface_text: The power to company- pel persons in charge of motor buses to stop only at certain places for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers is a matter which relates to motor traffic and there is a specific provision in sec- tion 68 2 r s of the Motor Vehicles Act for this specific purpose. They read as follows 68. 2 Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, rules under this section may be made with respect to all or any of the following matters, namely r prohibiting the picking up or setting down of passengers by stage or companytract carriages at specified places

issues.text: Whether the respondent has a fundamental right to use the Municipal bus stand

anchor.surface_text: This argument is as fallacious as the one put forward by Mr. Phadke on behalf of the respondent that he had a fundamental right to use the Municipal bus stand. Nobody has a fundamental right to use a land belonging to another without that persons permission or paying for it if necessary.

arguments.claim: No compulsion on anybody to park bus within municipal limits; can park outside for picking up/setting down passengers
arguments.court_response: The first proposition has only to be stated to be rejected. The person plying a motor bus for hire cannot exercise his trade or profession effectively if he is not allowed to set down or take up passengers within the limits of a town. The Municipal Council cannot do indirectly what it cannot do directly.

arguments.claim: If bus parks in municipal bus stand, it is using municipal land

anchor.surface_text: That if he parks the bus in the municipal bus stand he is using municipal land.

arguments.claim: Parking in municipal bus stand is with permission of the Municipality

anchor.surface_text: That this is with the permission of the Municipality.

arguments.claim: For permission to use municipal bus stand, permit is issued and fee charged

anchor.surface_text: That for this permission a permit is issued and a fee is charged.

arguments.court_reasoning: If for this permission the formality of the issue of a permit is followed and a fee is charged it cannot be said to be objectionable... Such a provision is permissible not under any provisions of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act but ... out of the right which the Municipal Council ... has

anchor.surface_text: The section itself does not enable the Municipal Council to require that permission should be obtained for any purpose. arguments.claim: Bye-laws not valid under s.358(7)(n); power to regulate/prohibit use as halting place does not compel use

anchor.surface_text: As regards clause n of sub-section 7 the regulating and prohibiting the stationing of carts on any ground under the control of the Council or the using of such ground as halting place of vehicles cannot be said to relate to the provision of a Municipal bus stand.

arguments.claim: Specific power required to compel use of municipal halting place; contrast with Madras Municipalities Act ss.270B,270C

anchor.surface_text: The power to regulate or prohibit the use of municipal land as halting place of vehicles cannot be used to compel people use such land as halting places. Such a power must be specifically given. Compare this section with sections 270-B and 270-C of the Madras District Municipalities Act

arguments.claim: Power to prohibit picking up/setting down passengers except at stands vests in State Government under Motor Vehicles Act s.68(2)(r)(s)

anchor.surface_text: The power to compel persons in charge of motor buses to stop only at certain places for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers is a matter which relates to motor traffic and there is a specific provision in section 68 2 r s of the Motor Vehicles Act

arguments.claim: s.76 Motor Vehicles Act deals with parking/standing places, not bus stands for passengers

anchor.surface_text: Under section 76 of the Motor Vehicles Act the State Government or any authority authorized in this behalf by the State Government may in consultation with the local authority having jurisdiction in the area concerned, determine places at which motor vehicles may stand

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court in error in holding bye-law 2 valid

holdings.text: Section 349(ii) of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961 does not apply to this case and does not enable the Municipal Council to compel buses to use the municipal bus stand

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that S. 349 ii does number apply to this case. The relevant portion of that section reads The Council may charge such fee as may be prescribed.for any permission granted under this Act for the temporary occupation of any land belonging to the Council. The section itself does number enable the Municipal Council to require that permission should be obtained for any purpose. It deals with levy of fees for permissions which are required to be taken for various purposes under other sections of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section deals only with levying fees for permissions already required under other provisions of the Act, such as ss. 187(3), 194, 223(4); does not authorize requiring permission or compelling use of bus stand

holdings.text: The bye-laws cannot be validly made under section 358(7)(f) or (n) of the Madhya Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1961

anchor.surface_text: Let us number companysider if under the provisions of section 358, already extracted, the Municipal Council can validly make the present bylaws. It is number possible to relate the provision of clause f of subsection 7 as having anything to do with the provision of a bus stand. As regards clause n of sub-section 7 the regulating and prohibiting the stationing of carts on any ground under the companytrol of the Council or the using of such ground as halting place of vehicles cannot be said to relate to the provision of a Municipal bus stand. The power to regulate or prohibit the use of municipal land as halting place of vehicles cannot be used to companypel people use such land as halting places. Such a power must be specifically given. Compare this section with sections 270-B and 270-C of the Madras District Municipalities Act, 1920,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses unrelated to providing bus stand; power to regulate or prohibit use of municipal land as halting place does not extend to compelling its use; requires specific statutory power, unlike Madras Act ss.270B-C

holdings.text: Municipal Council has no power under the Motor Vehicles Act to prohibit buses from picking up or setting down passengers except at the municipal bus stand

anchor.surface_text: The power to company- pel persons in charge of motor buses to stop only at certain places for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers is a matter which relates to motor traffic and there is a specific provision in sec- tion 68  2   r   s  of the Motor Vehicles Act for this specific purpose. They read as follows 68.  2  Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, rules under this section may be made with respect to all or any of the following matters, namely  r  prohibiting the picking up or setting down of passengers by stage or companytract carriages at specified places

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific power under s.68(2)(r)(s) vests in State Government for motor traffic regulation; s.76 concerns parking/standing places, not passenger pick-up/set-down; supported by precedents like T.B. Ibrahim and Municipal Board Pushkar

holdings.text: Bye-law 2 is invalid as the High Court erred in holding it valid

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the Madhya Pradesh High Court was in error in holding bye-law 2 valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory power under Municipalities Act or Motor Vehicles Act to compel exclusive use of municipal bus stand for passenger pick-up/set-down

holdings.text: Bye-laws 3 to 7 are invalid as they fall with bye-law 2

anchor.surface_text: Consequently we hold bye-law 2 as number valid and with it go the other bye-laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions for fees and permits depend on validity of compulsion under bye-law 2

holdings.text: There is no fundamental right to use land belonging to another without permission or payment

anchor.surface_text: Nobody has a fundamental right to use a land belonging to another without that persons permission or paying for it if necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent's claim of fundamental right to use municipal bus stand rejected as fallacious

holdings.text: Municipal Council may provide bus stand voluntarily and charge fees for its use as owner of property
holdings.reasoning_summary: Permissible as general property right, not statutory compulsion; propositions 2 and 3 unexceptionable; fee and permit ok for voluntary users

precedents.citation: T. B. Ibrahim v. R.T.C., Tanjore

anchor.surface_text: T. B. Ibrahim v. R.T.C., Tanjore   held that the expression duly numberified stand in the Motor Vehicles Act means a stand duly numberified by the Transport Authority. It was companytended before this Court that section 68 2   r  of the Motor Vehicles Act did number companyfer the power upon the transport authority to direct the fixing or the alteration of a bus-stand. This Court rejected that companytention. It pointed out that the section gives power to the Government to prohibit a specified place from being used for picking up or setting down passengers. This Court held that section 270-B, 270-C and 270-E of the Madras District Municipalities Act do number affect the power of the Transport Authority to regulate traffic companytrol or impose restrictions upon the licence of any such cart-stand.

precedents.case_name: T. B. Ibrahim v. R.T.C., Tanjore
precedents.cited_proposition: duly notified stand in the Motor Vehicles Act means a stand duly notified by the Transport Authority; s.68(2)(r) confers power to direct fixing of bus stand; Madras Municipalities Act ss.270-B, C, E do not affect Transport Authority's power
precedents.cited_holding: section 270-B, 270-C and 270-E of the Madras District Municipalities Act do number affect the power of the Transport Authority to regulate traffic companytrol or impose restrictions upon the licence of any such cart-stand

precedents.citation: Municipal. Board, Pushkar v. State Transport Authority, Rajasthan

anchor.surface_text: Municipal. Board, Pushkar v. State Transport Authority, Rajasthan  2  this Court pointed out that a bus stand meant a place where bus service companymenced or terminated and that section 86 dealt with parking places referred to in section 91 2   c  of the Motor Vehicles Act. The fixation of bus stands was held to be within section 68  2   r  of the Act and the power to issue the necessary numberification was held to be implied in that clause.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Board, Pushkar v. State Transport Authority, Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: bus stand is place where bus service commences or terminates; fixation of bus stands within s.68(2)(r) of Motor Vehicles Act; power to notify implied therein
precedents.cited_holding: The fixation of bus stands was held to be within section 68  2   r  of the Act and the power to issue the necessary numberification was held to be implied in that clause

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that S. 349 ii does number apply to this case. The relevant portion of that section reads The Council may charge such fee as may be prescribed.for any permission granted under this Act for the temporary occupation of any land belonging to the Council. The section itself does number enable the Municipal Council to require that permission should be obtained for any purpose. It deals with levy of fees for permissions which are required to be taken for various purposes under other sections of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Let us number companysider if under the provisions of section 358, already extracted, the Municipal Council can validly make the present bylaws. It is number possible to relate the provision of clause f of subsection 7 as having anything to do with the provision of a bus stand. As regards clause n of sub-section 7 the regulating and prohibiting the stationing of carts on any ground under the companytrol of the Council or the using of such ground as halting place of vehicles cannot be said to relate to the provision of a Municipal bus stand. The power to regulate or prohibit the use of municipal land as halting place of vehicles cannot be used to companypel people use such land as halting places. Such a power must be specifically given. Compare this section with sections 270-B and 270-C of the Madras District Municipalities Act, 1920,

anchor.surface_text: The power to company- pel persons in charge of motor buses to stop only at certain places for the purpose of taking up or setting down of passengers is a matter which relates to motor traffic and there is a specific provision in sec- tion 68  2   r   s  of the Motor Vehicles Act for this specific purpose. They read as follows 68.  2  Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, rules under this section may be made with respect to all or any of the following matters, namely  r  prohibiting the picking up or setting down of passengers by stage or companytract carriages at specified places

They read as follows 68.  2  Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, rules under this section may be made with respect to all or any of the following matters, namely  r  prohibiting the picking up or setting down of passengers by stage or companytract carriages at specified places
Therefore, we must hold that the Madhya Pradesh High Court was in error in holding bye-law 2 valid.
